choices.text: Laparoscopic bipolar coagulation
Laparoscopic monopolar hook
Ultrasonic harmonic scalpel
Uterine manipulator

questions.text: You are in the Operation Theater and observe the following instrument being used in laparoscopic surgery. Identify the instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Ultrasonic harmonic scalpel.

  • The image is of an ultrasonic harmonic scalpel
  • Hemostasis (Stopping bleeding) is an important component of laparoscopic surgeries. This can be achieved by the following methods
    • Electrosurgical Coagulation by heat (bipolar or monopolar systems)
    • Ultrasonic instruments: These disperse mechanical energy in such a way that the tissue is heated and coagulated. An inbuilt scissors can then cut the desiccated tissue.
    • Laser coagulation
    • Hemostatic clips
    • Laparoscopic suturing

Other Options

  • Option A: Laparoscopic bipolar coagulation is an electrical vessel sealing device and looks like this

 

  • Option B: Laparoscopic monopolar hook: This is used for cutting and has a monopolar current supplied through it. This is how it looks like: 

  • Option D: Uterine Manipulator: It is used in laparoscopic gyn surgeries like hysterectomy to manipulate or move the uterus to make the surgery easier. It is of different types and they look like this: 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Achieviing hemostasis (stopping bleeding) is an important component of laparoscopic surgeries. This can be achieved by the following methods
    • Electrosurgical Coagulation by heat (bipolar or monopolar systems)
    • Ultrasonic instruments: These disperse mechanical energy in such a way that the tissue is heated and coagulated. An inbuilt scissors can then cut the desiccated tissue.
    • Laser coagulation
    • Hemostatic clips
    • Laparoscopic suturing

Ref: Page no 771, Novak Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Air
Carbon dioxide
Oxygen
Nitrous oxide

questions.text: The gas commonly used for insufflation in gynecological laparoscopic procedures is:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Carbon dioxide.

  • Carbon dioxide is the most common gas used in laparoscopic surgeries
  • An ideal gas for insufflation of the abdominal cavity, increasing working and viewing space, should be
    • Cheap
    • Colorless
    • Not flammable
    • Inexplosive
    • Easily removed by the body
    • Non‚Äêtoxic to participants
  • Currently, carbon dioxide is the most frequently used gas for this purpose
  • Complications due to CO2:    
    • CO2 embolus
    • Hypercarbia

Educational Objective: 

  • The most common gas used for laparoscopic surgeries is CO2

 Ref: Page no 774, Novak Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Endo-bag
Colpotomy
Extending the trocar incision site
Resorption by leaving in situ

questions.text: A 34 y undergoes laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy for an ovarian cyst. Following the cystectomy, all can be methods of removal of the specimen except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Resorption by leaving in situ

The cyst wall cannot be left in situ. Leaving it in situ can leasd to infection and sepsis and hence it needs to be removed. There are various ways of removing a specimen in laparoscopy. 

Educational Objective

Laparoscopic removal of specimen can be done by any of the following

  • Morcellation (This means cutting up/ crushing the specimen by an instrument called a morcellator)
  • By enlarging any of the trocar insertion sites
  • Through a colpotomy (incision in the posterior vagina)
  • Putting the specimen in an endo-bag (This avoids spillage)

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 7th edition

choices.text: 1
2
3
4

questions.text: A 44y lady is planned for a total laparoscopic hysterectomy for fibroid uterus. In the image shown below, where should the primary port be placed?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 2 

  • The primary trocar placement in most gynecological surgeries is umbilical or supra-umbilical
  • Accessory or ancillary trocars are then placed laterally in the spino-umbilical line or in the midline or in the upper quadrants.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Point 1 is not used for primary or secodnary port placement for gyn surgeries
  • Option C & D: Points 3 and 4 are commonly used for secondary port placement

Educational objective: 

  • Insufflation with verres is usually done at the umbilicus or at the Palmers point
  • Primary port in gyn surgeries is usually umbilical/ supra-umbilical
  • Secondary ports are usually in the left or right spino-umblical line

 

Ref: Page no 273, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 11th edition

choices.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy
Total laparoscopic hysterectomy
Hysteroscopy and endometrial biopsy
LNG – IUD

questions.text: A 50y woman presents with complaints of repeated episodes of heavy bleeding after periods of amenorrhea for 6 months. On examination she is pale. Her BP is 140/90 mmHg. Abdominal examination is normal and on bimanual examination the uterus is normal size. A transvaginal scan reveals the following image. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Hysteroscopy and endometrial biopsy

  • This is a clinical picture of Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • The Transvaginal scan shown an increased endometrial thickness with cystic spaces
  • Any woman > 40 with AUB should be investigated for endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma
  • The gold standard for this is by doing a hysteroscopy and endometrial biopsy.

Other Options

  • Hysterecomy (either open or laparoscopic) is not directly indicated till a histopathology and diagnosis is at hand. Hysterectomy is preferred in endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. 
  • Similarly LNG-IUD is to be considered only after a histopathology rerport. It is the preferred management in endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. 

Ref: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng88/resources/heavy-menstrual-bleeding-assessment-and-management-pdf-1837701412549

choices.text: A common site of ureteric injury is the at the level of crossing of the uterine artery near the internal os
Intraoperative visualization of ureteric peristalsis is sufficient to exclude ureteric injury
The most common activity leading to injury is an attempt to obtain hemostasis
In laparoscopic hysterectomies, ureteral injury can present several days postoperative due to lateral thermal spread from cautery devices.

questions.text: All are true regarding ureteric injuries during hysterectomy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Intraoperative visualization of ureteric peristalsis  is sufficient to exclude ureteric injury

Ureteric injuries associated with gynecological surgery

  • Ureteric injury is common due to its anatomy:
    • Ureter has 2 components: abdominal and pelvic (each being 12 – 15 cm in length)
    • Enters the pelvic brim over the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
    • They then course medial to the internal iliac artery and its anterior branches
    • “Bridge under water”: The uterine artery (bridge) crosses over the ureter (water)
    • The ureters lie 1.5 cm lateral to the cervix where it enters the paracervical tissues in the “tunnel of Wertheim”
    • Once through his tunnel, the ureter turns medially and anteriorly over the vaginal fornix to enter the trigone of the bladder.
  • Vulnerable to injury in several gyn surgeries (Hysterectomy, adnexal surgery, retropubic surgery etc.)
  • Most common site of injury: At the ligation of cardinal ligaments and uterine vessels
  • Most common type of injury: Obstruction
  • Most common ‘activity’ leading to injury: Attempt to obtain hemostasis
  • Detected intraoperatively:  50% of the time
    • If ureteral injury is suspected, visualization of ureteric peristalsis is insufficient to diagnose injury
    • Integrity can be confirmed by
      • In abdominal surgeries, administering an IV coloring agent and watching for extravasation into the pelvis.
      • In vaginal surgeries, doing a cystoscopy and confirming urine efflux from the urine orifices by administration of an IV coloring agent.

 

Ref: Page no 936, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 11th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic hysterectomy
Ovarian cystectomy
Tubal recanalization
Vaginal hysterectomy

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used in which surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Laparoscopic hysterectomy

  • The instrument shown is a uterine manipulator
  • Uterine manipulator is used to assist movements of the uterus in laparoscopic surgeries, particularly in laparoscopic hysterectomies.
  • The cup at the end also acts as a marker for identifying the vaginal vault and this also makes hysterectomies easier
  • They also help in other laparoscopic surgeries as they can manipulate the uterus and assist the surgeon during different laparoscopic pelvic surgeries.

Ref: Page no 740, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 11th edition

choices.text: Cervical cancer
Fundal fibroids
Uterine prolapse.
Enterocele repair

questions.text: A 50y woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy for endometrial hyperplasia. A Moskowitz’s surgery is done alongwith the hysterectomy. What is a Moskowitz surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterocele repair

  • The goal of the Moskowitz procedure is to fix and suture the strong connective tissue that normally supports the uterus to the top of the vagina, thus preventing it from “falling out.”
  • In this procedure, the pouch between the rectum and the vagina is reduced with a purse-string type suture.
  • This prevents enterocele formation
  • Another procedure to prevent enterocele repair is called Halban’s procedure

choices.text: Boyle’s apparatus
Camera system
Light source
Electronic insufflator

questions.text: You are observing a laparoscopic hysterectomy in the Operation Theater. You note the following equipment and wonder what it is? Identify this equipment
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Electronic insufflator.

  • This is an image of an electronic gas insufflator
  • The insufflator regulates the rate of inflow of gas to create/ maintain the intra-abdominal pressure.
  • It shows 3 readings
  1. Intra-abdominal pressure
  2. Rate of gas flow
  3. Volume of gas used
  • There is a gas cable which connects the insufflator to the Verres needle/ port for inflow of gas.

Other Options

  • Option A: Boyle's Apparatus: This is the anesthesia machine wherein pressurised gases are supplied by cylinders or pipelines and controls the flow of gases before passing them through a vaporiser and delivering the resulting mixture to the patient via the breathing circuit.
  • Opton B: Camera system: This includes the camera head, monitor and camera system 
  • Opton C: Light source: This includes the main light source (xenon/ LED) and the light cable through which the light is transmitted and fits onto the laprroscope

Educational Objective: 

  • In laparoscopy surgery, pneumoperitoneum is created and then the primary port (through which the laparoscope is introduced) and secondary ports (through which laproscopic instruments are introduced) are created. 
  • The laparoscopic equipment conists of
    • The laproscope
    • The laprroscopic instruments
    • The laproscopic tower which includes the following equipment
      • The monitor
      • Camera system
      • Electronic infufflator
      • CO2 gas cylinder
      • Light source

Ref: Page no 759, Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Glycine
Mannitol
Normal saline
Sorbitol

questions.text: A 28y old woman is undergoing a hysteroscopic myomectomy for a type 0 submucosal fibroid. The surgeon is using a monopolar resectoscope for the same. All can be used as distension media except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Normal saline

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy:

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance and fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, non conductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

Other Options:

  • Option A: Glycine; Option B: Mannitol and Option D: Sorbitol: These are all low viscosity non conductive fluids and are used when monopolar current is used

 

Educational Objective: 

  • If using monopolar cautery in hysteroscopic surgeries: DO NOT use Normal saline as a fluid media. Instead, glycine and mannitol can be used
  • If using bipolar cautery in hysteroscopic surgeries: Normal saline can be safely used. 

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novak's Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Air
Glycine
Normal Saline
Carbon dioxide

questions.text: All can be used as distension media during diagnostic hysteroscopy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Air

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy. It is rarely used
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood.
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance and fluid overload.
  • Low viscosity, non conductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

Educational Objective: Hysteroscopy is done by distending the uterine cavity with fluid media to visualize the uterine cavity. The most common media used are normal saline, glycine and mannitol. Rarely gaseous media (CO2) can be used. 

Ref: Page no 793, Novak's Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Jain Point
Lee Huang Point
Palmer Point
Parker Point

questions.text: The point shown in the image below is used as an entry point for creation of pneumo-peritoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. This point is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Palmer point

 

Points of laparoscopic entry for creation of pneumoperitoneum in gynecological surgeries are as shown

 

 

Other Options: Described in the table below

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

 

Ref: Page no 273, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 11th edition

choices.text: Abdominal aorta
Inferior epigastric
Internal iliac
Superior epigastric

questions.text: A 23y woman undergoes a diagnostic laparoscopy for infertility. On putting the secondary trocar, she starts bleeding profusely from the port site. Which vessel is injured?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Inferior epigastric.

  • The vessels most commonly injured during secondary/ accessory trocar placement are the superficial inferior epigastric vessels.
  • The inferior epigastric artery is a  branch of the femoral artery and vein and they go cephalad in each lower quadrant
  • The deep inferior epigastric vessels can also be injured.
  • These are branches of the external iliac artery and course cephalad and lie deep to the rectus sheath and muscle.
  • Great vessel injury (abdominal aorta and vena cava, common iliac and their branches) commonly occur following insertion of an insufflation needle (Verres needle) or the tip of the primary trocar

Educational Objective: Remember the inferior epigastric vessels commonly get injured during secondary port placement in laparoscopy surgery

Ref: Page no 780, Novak’s Gynecology, 15th edition

choices.text: The Veress needle is blocked
The Veress needle is extra-peritoneal
The Veress needle is intraperitoneal
The Veress needle has entered the bowel

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady is undergoing a laparoscopic tubal ligation. On introducing the Veress needle, the pressure on the electronic insufflator is noted to be 2 mmHg. What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Veress needle is intra-peritoneal

Correct placement of Veress needle (i.e. intraperitoneal placement) is verified by

  1. Hanging drop method
    • A small amount of saline is placed on the tip of the Veress needle
    • The saline drops in the peritoneal cavity when there is negative intra-peritoneal pressure)
  2. Syringe barrel test
    • A 10ml syringe with normal saline is attached to the Veress needle and saline is pushed inside
    • Aspiration is done
    • If the needle position is correct i.e, intra-peritoneal, the fluid cannot be withdrawn
  3. Intra-abdominal pressure is low (< 10 mmHg) on the electronic insufflator
  4. There is free flow of gas
  5. Obliteration of liver dullness on percussion

Other Options

  • Option A: The Veress needle is blocked: If the verres was blocked, the gas would not flow inside and the pressure shown would be very high
  • Option B: The Veress needle is extra-peritoneal: Again the pressure would be very high and there will not be free flow of gas
  • Option C: The Veress needle has entered the bowel: Again the pressure would be very high and there will not be free flow of gas

Educational Objective

  • Remember that in laproscopic surgeries, initial intra-abdominal pressure is low (< 10mmHg) when the verres is inserted
  • The initial gas pressures put are 15-20 mmHg for port insertions
  • This is then brought down to 10-15 mHg during surgery

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 7th edition

choices.text: Asherman syndrome
Cervical fibroid
Submucosal fibroid
Endometrial polyp

questions.text: All are indications of operative hysteroscopy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Cervical fibroid

Indications for operative hysteroscopy include:

  • Endometrial polyp
  • Submucosal fibroids
  • Lysis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome)
  • Endometrial ablation in AUB
  • Septoplasty (Resection of septum in a septate uterus)
  • Removal of missing IUD/ Foreign body in the uterine cavity
  • Endometrial biopsy
  • Tubal cannulation under hysteroscopic and laparoscopic guidance
  • Insertion of Essure device for female sterilization

A cervical fibroid is best removed by a laproscopic myomectomy or a laprotomy and myomectomy. 

Educational objective: Hysteroscopic surgeries are done in uterine cavity or endometrial pathologies. Anything outside the uterine cavity cannot be approached hysteroscopically

Ref: Page no 512, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Infertility
Postmenopausal bleeding
Puberty menorrhagia
Recurrent pregnancy loss

questions.text: A 34y woman underwent a hysteroscopy for AUB. All are indications of diagnostic hysteroscopy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Puberty menorrhagia

Indications of Diagnostic hysteroscopy include:

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding in the peri-menopausal age group
  • Evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding (if endometrial thickness ≥ 5 mm)
  • Infertility
  • Mullerian anomalies (usually combined with laparoscopy for diagnosis)
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss
  • Misplaced IUD
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Suspected AV malformation

Puberty menorhagia is NOT an indication for hysteroscopy. 

  • The most common cause of puberty menorrhagia ia anovulation followed by coagulopathy and thyroid disorders
  • Hence hysteroscopy is not going to help in puberty menorrhagia unless there is suspicion of an intra-uterine lesion. 

Educational Objective: Diagnostic hysteroscopy is indicated when there is AUB in the perimenopausal/ postmenopausal age group. In these patients, a hysteroscopy guided endometrial biopsy is the gold standard for obtaining an endometrial biopsy

Ref: Page no 512, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Cervical fibroids
Intramural fibroids
Submucous fibroids
Subserous fibroids

questions.text: The STEP-W classification is used to classify
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Submucous fibroids

  • The “STEPW or Lasmar” Classification is a Hysteroscopic submucous myoma classification
  • It is a preoperative classification of submucous myomas for evaluating the viability and the degree of difficulty of hysteroscopic myomectomy.
  • The older ESGE classification, also described by FIGO (type 0, 1 and 2) considers only the degree of penetration of the myoma into the myometrium and sometimes it is not a good predictor of myomectomy difficulty.
  • The STEPW classification considers
    • The degree of penetration of the myoma into the myometrium
    • Distance of the base of the myoma from the uterine wall
    • Size of the fibroid
    • Topography of the uterine cavity.
  • Each parameter receives a score, and the total sum of them indicates the myoma group

Educational Objective: 

  • STEP-W Classification: This is a hysteroscopic classification of sub-mucosal fibroid
  • FIGO Classification: This is for classification of all fibroids

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22819007/

choices.text: Bronchoscope
Hysteroscope
Laparoscope
Proctoscope

questions.text: As a 1st year resident, you are asked to prepare the gynecological instruments for the final year MBBS viva. The OT sister hands you the following instrument. Identify the instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hysteroscope.

  • The image seen is of a hysteroscope with an operating sheath
  • A hysteroscope is used to visualize the endometrial cavity
  • Hysteroscopes can be Diagnostic or Therapeutic
  • Distension media (usually liquid like saline or glycine) is used to distend the uterine cavity for visualization
  • The scope shown has an operative sheath through which instruments like scissors/ graspers can be introduced.

Other options

  • Option A: Bronchoscope

  • Option B: Laproscope 

  • Option D: Proctoscope

Educational Objective: A hysteroscope is an instrument used to visualize the uterine cavity. Fluid media is used to distend the uterine cavity during hysteroscopy. 

Ref:  Page no 793, Novak's Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Mackenrodt ligament
Uterosacral ligament
Round ligament
Infundibulopelvic ligament

questions.text: A 57yr lady presents with 30 utero-vaginal prolapse. She undergoes a vaginal hysterectomy. All the ligaments are cut in a vaginal hysterectomy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Infundibulopelvic ligament

Steps of vaginal hysterectomy

  • Circumferential Incision given around the cervix
  • Bladder separated anteriorly and posteriorly, the pouch if Douglas opened
  • Laterally the following are clamped cut and ligated (from below upwards)
    • The uterosacral ligaments (bilateral)
    • The Mackenrodt ligaments (bilateral)
    • Uterine arteries (bilateral)
    • The round ligament/ ovarian ligament complex (bilateral)
    • Effort is made to remove both fallopian tubes.
  • The infundibulopelvic ligaments are not routinely cut in a vaginal hysterectomy unless there is an associated ovarian pathology and the pvary needs to be removed

 

Ref: Page no 754, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 10th edition

choices.text: Decreased hospital stay
Less post-operative pain
Less incidence of ureteric injury
Increased operating time

questions.text: A 46y lady has to undergo a hysterectomy for adenomyosis. She wants to know the advantages and disadvantages of a laparoscopic hysterectomy compared to an abdominal hysterectomy. All are true regarding laparoscopic hysterectomy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. less incidence of ureteric injury

Laparoscopic Hysterectomy compared with Abdominal Hysterectomy

  • Faster return to normal activity
  • Shorter duration of hospital stay
  • Fewer wound or abdominal wall infections
  • Longer operating time
  • Higher rate of lower urinary tract (bladder and ureter) injuries
  • Improved quality of life in the first months and at 4 years post-surgery
  • No evidence of difference in satisfaction or major long-term complications
  • No evidence of difference in overall cost (limited studies)

 

Ref: https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/06/choosing-the-route-of-hysterectomy-for-benign-disease

choices.text: Common peroneal nerve
Femoral nerve
Great saphenous nerve
Pudendal nerve

questions.text: A 62-yr old woman undergoes a vaginal hysterectomy for utero-vaginal prolapse. Following surgery, there is paresthesia of the lateral side of the leg and you notice there is foot drop. Compression of which nerve is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Common peroneal nerve

  • Common peroneal nerve compression occurs in lithotomy position
  • The nerve is compressed between the lateral head of the fibula and the bar holding the legs.
  • IT is associated with paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the leg and foot and with foot drop

 

Ref: https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1111/tog.12696

choices.text: Adenomyosis
Endometrial hyperplasia
Leiomyoma
Uterine prolapse

questions.text: The most common indication for hysterectomy is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Leiomyoma

  • Indications for hysterectomy
    • Benign
      • AUB
      • Leiomyoma
      • Adenomyosis
      • Endometriosis
      • Pelvic organ prolapse
      • PID
      • Chronic pelvic pain
      • Obstetric hysterectomy
    • Malignant
      • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia
      • Invasive cervical cancer
      • Atypical endometrial hyperplasia
      • Endometrial cancer
      • Ovarian cancer
      • Fallopian tube cancer
      • Gestational trophoblastic tumors

 

  • The most common indication for hysterectomy is LEIOMYOMA (fibroid uterus)

 

Ref: Page no 728, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 10th edition

choices.text: Bilateral Ovaries
One side ovary
Bilateral Fallopian tubes
Bilateral Fallopian tubes and ovaries

questions.text: While performing hysterectomy for a 48-year-old woman, which of the following structures should be removed along with the uterus?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Bilateral fallopian tube

  • Opportunistic salpingectomy, I.e. removal of bilateral fallopian tubes at the time of a hysterectomy is recommended.
  • This decreases the risk of ovarian cancer in patients undergoing pelvic surgery for benign disease.
  • The ovaries are not routinely recommended to be removed at hysterectomy unless the patient has risk factors for ovarian cancer (family history/ ovarian pathology)

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30913199/

choices.text: High precision with absence of tremor
Increased tactile feedback
The robotic image is stereoscopic
Robotic movements are intuitive and have 7 degrees of movements

questions.text: A 43-yr woman who is to undergo hysterectomy is curious and wants to know more about robotic hysterectomy. All are advantages of robotic hysterectomy except
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Increased tactile feedback

Robotic surgery is a newer technique of performing laproscopic surgeries in whch the surgeon sits a t the console and operates the robotic arms which are introduced into different ports in the patient abdomen (similar to laproscopic surgery). It is an upcoming branch in which many technically difficult surgeries can be performed with ease especially in pelvic surgeries. 

Advantages of robotic surgery

  • Image is stereoscopic (3D)
  • Movements are intuitive
  • The instrument tips are articulated such as to have 70 of movement (mimics the movement of the hands and wrist) – more dexterity
  • Suturing is easier
  • High precision
  • Absence of tremor
  • Increased accuracy
  • Reduction in surgeon fatigue and stress

Disadvantage

  • Absence of tactile feedback (This means the feeling of touch is absent)
  • Cost
  • Training and learning curve
  • Increased Dependence on technology

Educational Objective:

Robotic surgery has increased precision and dexterity because of the 7 degrees of movement mimicing a human hand but the absence of tactile feedback and the cost are major disadvantages. 

Ref: Page no 510, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Hysteroscopic myomectomy
In vitro fertilization
Laparoscopic myomectomy
Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 24y lady presented with infertility of 2 years duration. A hysteroscopy revealed the following. Semen parameters and ovulation were normal. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

 

  • This is a hysteroscopic image of a submucous fibroid.

  • As the patient has infertility, the best management would be to remove the fibroid (myomectomy)

    • Indications of myomectomy in infertility are:

      • All submucosal fibroids

      • Intramural fibroids that

        • > 5 cm

        • Distort the endometrial cavity

  • Fibroids with > 50% protruding into the endometrium are best removed by hysteroscopy.

  • Submucosal fibroid removal improves fertility, intramural fibroid removal may or may not imprive fertility, subserosal fibroid removal does not affect fertility

  • Hence the best management is hysteroscopic myomectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated in infertile women with large intramural fibroids (> 5 cm) or those intramural fibroids which are distorting the endometrial cavty

  • IVF is not directly indicated. Even if the patient requires an IVF eventually, the submucus fbroid will have to be removed

  • Uterine Artery Embolization is NOT indicated in women who want to convieve

 

Ref: Page no 280, DC Dutta‚Äôs Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3304294/#:~:text=Laparoscopic%20myomectomy%20in%20infertility,-In%20spite%20of&text=Indications%3A%20Universally%20accepted%20indications%20include,3%20cm%2C%20and%20multiple%20fibroids.

choices.text: Infundibulopelvic ligament
Ovarian ligament
Round ligament
Transverse Cervical ligament

questions.text: A 45-yr woman is undergoing a total abdominal hysterectomy for a large fibroid uterus. She has a family history of ovarian cancer. Which ligament is clamped, cut, and ligated if the ovaries are removed?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. infundibulopelvic ligament

  • The ovaries are attached medially to the uterus by the ovarian ligament and laterally to the pelvic wall by the Infundibulopelvic ligament (aka suspensory ligament of the ovary)
  • During a hysterectomy, if the ovaries need to be retained, the ovarian ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.
  • During a hysterectomy, if the ovaries need to be removed, we have to clamp laterally i.e. the Infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut, and ligated.

Ref: Page no 734, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 10th edition

choices.text: Reverse Trendelenburg
Semi-Fowler
Supine
Trendelenburg

questions.text: A 48yr lady was planned for a total laparoscopic hysterectomy for adenomyosis. Which is the best position for this surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Trendelenburg.

  • Trendelenburg position:
    • The body is laid supine  on a 15–300 incline with the feet elevated above the head.
    • The Trendelenburg position is used in pelvic surgery. It allows better access to the pelvic organs as gravity pulls the intra-abdominal organs away from the pelvis
  •  The Reverse Trendelenburg position: The body is supine on an incline but with the head being elevated.
  • In Fowler's position, also known as sitting position: Typically used for neurosurgery and shoulder surgeries
  • Supine Position:
    • Also known as Dorsal Decubitus
    • The most frequently used position for procedures.
    • In this position, the patient is face-up. The patient's arms should be tucked at the patient's sides or flexed and secured across the body or extended and secured on padded arm boards
    • Supine position is commonly used for intracranial, cardiac, abdominal, endovascular, laparoscopic, lower extremity procedures, and ENT, neck, and face procedures

 

Ref: Page no 764, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology, 16th edition

choices.text: 1,2,3,4
3,1,2,4
2,1,3,4
1,3,2,4

questions.text:
In an abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, the following structures are clamped, cut, and ligated in what order?

 

  1. Infundibulopelvic ligament
  2. Mackenrodt ligaments
  3. Round ligament
  4. Uterosacral ligament
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 3,1,2,4.

Steps of an Abdominal hysterectomy

  • After entering the peritoneal cavity, the following structures are clamped, cut and ligated (from above downwards)
    • Bilateral round ligaments
    • Bilateral ovarian ligaments (if ovaries are preserved) or bilateral Infundibulopelvic ligaments if ovaries are removed
    • Bilateral uterine arteries are skeletonized and then clamped cut and ligated
    • Bilateral Mackenrodt ligaments
    • Bilateral uterosacral ligaments
  • The angles of the vaginal vault are clamped, and the uterus is removed
  • The vault is closed with sutures

 

Ref: Page no 734, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology, 10th edition

choices.text: McCall Culdoplasty to correct an enterocele.
Sacrospinous fixation
Suturing the uterosacral ligaments to the vaginal cuff
Suturing the vaginal cuff to the round ligaments

questions.text: A 65-yr woman undergoes a vaginal hysterectomy for second degree uterovaginal prolapse. She is very worried that she should not have a vault prolapse. Which of the following is NOT a step taken at the time of vaginal hysterectomy to prevent vault prolapse?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Suturing the vaginal cuff to the round ligaments

  • Following abdominal or vaginal hysterectomy, there is always a risk of vault prolapse.
  • The following steps at the time of hysterectomy, prevent the occurrence of post hysterectomy vaginal vault prolapse:
  1. McCall Culdoplasty at the time of vaginal hysterectomy is effective in preventing subsequent Post Hysterectomy Vault Prolapse.
  2. Suturing the cardinal and uterosacral ligaments to the vaginal cuff at the time of hysterectomy is effective in preventing post hysterectomy vault prolapse following both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomies.
  3. Sacrospinous fixation (SSF) at the time of vaginal hysterectomy should be considered when the vault descends to the introitus during closure.
  • Suturing the vaginal cuff to the round ligament will not help prevent vault prolapse as the round ligament is not a tru supporting ligament

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg-46.pdf

choices.text: Artery forceps
Laparoscopic grasper
Laparoscopic insufflator
Verres needle

questions.text: A 34 year P2L2 is undergoing a laparoscopic tubal ligation. In laparoscopic surgery, which instrument is used to create pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Verres needle

  • An important part of laparoscopic surgeries is creation of pneumoperitoneum

The image below is of a Verres needle which is used to create a pneumoperitoneum

  • It is typically inserted at the level of the umbilicus as there is no fat of muscle at this site.
  • Palmer’s point is preferred if adhesions are anticipated. This point is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the midclavicular line.
  • Intraperitoneal placement of the needle is confirmed by
    • Drop test: place a drop of saline on the hub of the needle and life the abdominal wall; the drop is sucked in
    • The insufflator will show a reading of intraperitoneal pressure < 10 mmHg (single digit reading)
    • Push 5 ml of saline in the peritoneal cavity and then attempt to aspirate it. No fluid can be aspirated if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity.
    • Liver dullness is obliterated if CO2 is flowing intraperitoneally.

Other Options

1. Option A:  Artery Forceps: This is not used in laparoscopic surgery. It is an instrument used in open surgeries and is used to hold the peritoneum and also to hold small bleeding vessels. 

2. Option B: Laparoscopic grasper: This is a laparoscopic operative instrument used to assist in various laparoscopic surgeries

3. Option C: Laparoscopic insufflator: This is the equipment which controls and measures the amount of CO2 entering the abdomen through the verres needle/ trocar

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Page no 273, The Linde’s Operative Gynecology 11th edition

choices.text: A pedunculated submucous myoma
Myoma with > 50% endo-cavitary component
Myoma with < 50% endo-cavitary component
Myoma with surface touching the endometrium

questions.text: A 41y old woman was diagnosed to have a submucous fibroid on a diagnostic hysteroscopy that she underwent for heavy menstrual bleeding. She was told that the fibroid was not removed hysteroscopically as it was a type 2 fibroid as per the FIGO classification of fibroid uterus. What is a type 2 fibroid?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myoma with < 50%  endo cavitary component.

 

Classification of Fibroids

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pedunculated sub-serous fibroid: This is a type 7 fibroid

 

Option B: Myoma with > 50% endo-cavitary component: This is a type 1 fibroid

 

Option D: Myoma with surface touching the endometrium: This is a type 3 fibroid

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Type 0 and type 1 fibroids can be removed hysteroscopically (Hysteroscopic myomectomy)
  • Type 2 and above fibroids are best removed by laparoscopy/ laparotomy

 

Ref: https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ijgo.12666

choices.text: Hysteroscopic polypectomy
Laparoscopic myomectomy
Total abdominal hysterectomy
Total laparoscopic hysterectomy

questions.text: A 40y parous woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding for 6 months. On examination, she was pale, her BP was 110/ 80 mmHg. Abdominal examination was normal. Bimanual examination revealed a normal sized uterus. A transvaginal scan showed the following image. Which would be the best management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Hysteroscopic polypectomy

  • The clinical scenario is of Abnormal Uterine Bleeding and the Ultrasound shows an endometrial polyp which is distending the uterine cavity.
  • Another differential diagnosis is a submucosal fibroid
  • Both will require a hysteroscopic polypectomy/ myomectomy and this is the best management option for this patient

Other Options:

  • Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy is not indicated as even if it is a submucosal fibroid, it wd best be removed via a  hysteroscope. 
  • Option C and D: Hysterectomy (open or laparoscopy) is not indicated in the given scenario as removing the polyp should reduce her symmptoms. It would only be indicated if there is evidence of endometrial hyperplasia with atypia or malignancy in the polyp on histopathology. 

Educational Objective: An endometrial polyp is best removed by hysteroscopic polypectomy

Ref: Page no 512, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Estrogen + Progesterone
Hysteroscopic Adhesiolysis
Hysteroscopic polypectomy
Only progesterone

questions.text: A 35y woman presents with secondary amenorrhea. She does not respond to either a progesterone challenge test or an estrogen + progesterone challenge test. She gives a h/o D & C 2 years earlier for a missed abortion. An HSG reveals the following. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

  • This HSG shows a uterine cavity with iregular filling defects seen. 
  • This is characteristic of Asherman syndrome (Intra uterine synechiae)
  • In patients with intra-uterine adhesions (Asherman Syndrome); the HSG shows an irregular uterine cavity (moth eaten appearance of the uterine cavity) as is seen in the image.
  • This usually occurs following an instrumentation in the uterine cavity like a D & C (As is mentioned in this case)
  • Management is Hysteroscopic resection of the adhesions (Adhesiolysis)

Other Options

  • Option A: Estrogen + Progesterone has already been given, the patient has not had bleeding. It is useful in patients with ovarian cause of secondary amenorrhea. 
  • Option C: Hysteroscopic polypectomy: An HSG would show a well defined space occupying lesion and not an irregular appearance as in this HSG
  • Option D: Progesterone only: Only useful in anovular cycles like PCOS. This patient has not responded to progesterone earlier also. 

Educational Objective

  • Asherman Syndrome on HSG appears as an irregular uterine cavity
  • It presents as secondary amenorrhea or hypomenorrhoea or infertility
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

Ref: Page no 512, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: 3 cm below the left subcostal margin in the midclavicular line
3 cm below the right subcostal margin in the midclavicular line
5 cm below the left subcostal margin in the midclavicular line
Left paraumbilical region at the level of umbilicus

questions.text: A 46y woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy for multiple uterine fibroids. She has had multiple surgoeries in the past and the gynecologist decides to place the Verres needle at the Palmer’s point to create pneumoperitoneum. Where is this point located?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 3 cm below the left subcostal margin in the midclavicular line

Points of laparoscopic entry for creation of pneumoperitoneum in gynecological surgeries are as shown

Educational Objective: 

 

Ref: Page no 273, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 11th edition

choices.text: Adenomyosis
Submucous fibroid
Uterovaginal prolapse
Endometrial hyperplasia

questions.text: All are indications of a total laparoscopic hysterectomy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Uterovaginal prolapse

  • In uterovaginal prolapse, the surgery preferred is vaginal hysterectomy and not a total laproscopic hysterectomy. 
  • A laparoscopic hysterectomy need not be done for a uterine prolapse as the uterus is outside and a vaginal hysterectomy is preferred
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive surgery that can replace most benign indications of a hysterectomy including fibroid uterus, adenomyosis, endometrial hyperplasia and CIN 3. 

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Adenomyosis: Hysterectomy for adenomyosis can be done abdominally or laproscopically, robotically or vaginally 
  • Option B: Submucous Fibroid: Hysterectomy for submucosal fibroid can be done abdominally, laproscopically, robotically or vaginally 
  • Option C: Endometrial Hyperplasia: Hysterectomy for submucosal fibroid can be done abdominally, laproscopically, robotically or vaginally 

Educational Objective: 

Routes of hysterectomy include

   1. Abdominal route (laparotomy): This is preferred for large uteruses or if hysterectomy is done for malignant condition or if laproscopic facilities are not available/ laparoscopy is contra-indicated like in cardio-pulmonary conditions

2. Laparoscopy and robotic hysterectomy: Can be done for all benign conditions and has more or less replaced abdomnal hysterectomies.. C/i to laparoscopy include cardio-pulmonary conditions and hysterectomy for advanced malignancy. 

3. Vaginal hysterectomy: 

  • This is mostly done in women with uterine prolapse
  • It can also be done in women without prolapse with uterus size < 14 weeks (like small fibroids or adenomyosis) and is called as Non Descent Vaginal Hysterectomy (NDVH)

 

 

Ref: Page no 756, Novak Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: 50 mmHg
25 mmHg
15 mmHg
5 mmHg

questions.text: A gynecologist is doing a laparoscopic myomectomy for a 32 year woman with a large intramural  fibroid. The intra-abdominal pressure needed to be maintained for optimum gynecological laparoscopic surgery is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 15 mm Hg

  • Laparoscopic surgery involves creating pneumo-peritoneum wherein CO2 gas is introduced in the peritoneal cavity. 
  • At the beginnng of laparoscopic surgery, CO2 is insufflated to 25-30 mmHg for positioning of ports. This reduces the chance of trauma to the bowel or post abdominal wall as there is more gas inside the abdomen. 
  • After placement of cannulas, the pressure should be dropped to 10-15 mmHg. This reduces the risk of hypercarbia.

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laparoscopic surgery involves creating pneumo-peritoneum wherein CO2 gas is introduced in the peritoneal cavity. 
  • At the beginnng of laparoscopic surgery, CO2 is insufflated to 25-30 mmHg for positioning of ports. This reduces the chance of trauma to the bowel or post abdominal wall as there is more gas inside the abdomen. 
  • After placement of cannulas, the pressure should be dropped to 10-15 mmHg. This reduces the risk of hypercarbia.

Ref: Page no 761, Novak Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Severe cardiopulmonary disease
Advanced malignancy
Generalized peritonitis
Uterus > 16 weeks size

questions.text: All are contra-indications of total laparoscopic hysterectomy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Uterus >16 weeks size

The contraindications to laparoscopy in gynae surgery are:

  • Severe cardiopulmonary disease
  • Hemodynamically unstable patient
  • Significant hemoperitoneum
  • Generalized peritonitis
  • Advanced malignancy
  • Large pelvic tumor
  • Extensive peritoneal adhesions
  • Advance pregnancy

Educational Objective: A large uterus is NOT a contra-indication for laparoscopic surgery. 

Ref: Page no 507, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology

choices.text: Leiomyoma
Adenomyosis
Simple ovarian cyst
Endometrial hyperplasia

questions.text: All are indications of abdominal hysterectomy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Simple ovarian cyst

Indications for abdominal hysterectomy include

Benign diseases

  • Leiomyoma
  • Adenomyosis
  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Endometriosis
  • Pelvic Inflammatory diseases
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding

Malignant disease

  • Microinvasive cervical cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

 

Ref: Page no 728, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 10th edition

choices.text: Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis
Fluid from wetting the surgeon
Fluids running out during the procedure
Electrolyte imbalance in the patient

questions.text: Fluid management during hysteroscopy is important to prevent?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Electrolyte imbalance in the patient.

  • During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels.
  • Increased fluid absorption is seen in
    • Higher intrauterine pressure
    • Longer procedure duration
    • Deep myometrial penetration
    • Large uterus
  • Excessive absorption of hypotonic electrolyte free fluids, such as 1.5% glycine and 3% sorbitol, can cause hypo-osmolality, hyponatremia, cerebral edema, hypotonic encephalopathy, permanent neurologic injury, heart failure, pulmonary edema, and death.
  • Excessive absorption of normal saline is not associated with hyponatremia; however, it can cause volume overload, right-sided heart failure, pulmonary edema, and death.
  • Fluid deficit can be estimated by manual calculation or by use of an automated fluid management system.
    • When using hypotonic solutions, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000mL for healthy patients and 750mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
    • For normal saline, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2,500mL for healthy patients and 750mL for those with cardiovascular disease.
  • Fluid absorption can be reduced by
    • Pre-operative treatment with GnRH agonists
    • Intraoperative injection of dilute vasopressin (0.05 U/mL)
    • Using the lowest intrauterine pressure that provides adequate visualization
    • Intrauterine pressure should be below the mean arterial pressure.
  •  If excessive absorption of fluid occurs with a hypotonic fluid; obtain serum electrolytes and the patient should be evaluated for volume overload.
    •  Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output
    • Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and is managed in intensive care.
  • Fluid overload from normal saline can be managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40 mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis: As the fluid used is sterile and is quickly absorbed intra-peritoneally, peritonitis is an unlikely complication
  • Option B: Fluid from wetting the surgeon: The surgeon wears protective clothing during hysteroscopy.
  • Option C: Fluids running out during the procedure: The fluid if finished, is replaced with another unit

Educational Objective: Measurement of fluid deficit (Fluid going inside - Fluid coming outside) is of utmost importance in hysteroscopic surgeries as the amount of fluid getting absorbed in the body (fluid deficit) will cause electrolyte imabalance, pulmonary edema and cardiac failure if excessive. 

Ref:

https://www.exxcellence.org/list-of-pearls/fluid-management-at-hysteroscopy/?categoryName=&searchTerms=&featured=False&bookmarked=False&sortColumn=date&sortDirection=Descending

choices.text: Intrauterine adhesions
Transverse vaginal septum
Uterine septum
Unicornuate uterus

questions.text: A 30y woman with recurrent pregnancy loss was undergoing evaluation. A hysteroscopy done revealed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Uterine septum

  • This is the hysteroscopic image of a septate uterus
  • A septate uterus can be partial/ complete
  • Clinical presentation
    • Infertility
    • Abortions/ Recurrent pregnancy loss
    • Preterm labor
    • Malpresentations
    • Retained placenta
  • Diagnosis
    • Hysterosalpingography
    • Sonosalpingography
    • 3-D USG
    • MRI
    • Hysteroscopy: Best method to diagnose
  • Treatment:
    • Hysteroscopic septal resection using a resectoscope/ bipolar cautery/ scissors

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Intra-uterine adhesions on hysteroscopy will appear as shown below

  • Option B: Transverse Vaginal Septum: This is best diagnosed on clinical exam and MRI and not on hysteroscopy
  • Option D: Unicornate uterus: This is also best diagnosed on MRI. On hysteroscopy, the cavity of a unicornuate uterus appears small and narrow like this

Educational Objective: 

  • A septate uterus causes infertility, abortions, recurrent pregnancy loss, preterm labor and malpresentations
  • It is best diagnosed by an MRI (non invasive) and a hysteroscope (invasive)
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic septoplasty

Ref: Page no 46, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology. 6th edition

choices.text: Hysteroscopic septal resection
Hysteroscopic Adhesiolysis
In-vitro fertilization
Tubal recanalization

questions.text: A 34y woman with a history of 2 previous abortions presents with secondary infertility. On evaluation, this was seen on hysteroscopy. What is the nest management option?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

  • This is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions (aka Asherman Syndrome)
  • It can occur after instrumentation of the uterine cavity leading to destruction of endometrium
  • Symptoms
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhea
    • Infertility
  • In patients with intra-uterine adhesions (Asherman Syndrome); the HSG shows an irregular uterine cavity (moth eaten appearance of the uterine cavity)
  • This usually occurs following an instrumentation in the uterine cavity
  • Management is Hysteroscopic resection of the adhesions (Adhesiolysis)

Ref: Page no 512, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

choices.text: Fluid for distension
Gas insufflator
Hysteroscope
Light source

questions.text: A 20 year old lady is to undergo an operative hysteroscopy for hysteroscopic polypectomy. As an intern, you are asked to check if all the instruments and equipment are ready in the operation theater. All are used in hysteroscopy except.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Gas insufflator

Hysteroscopy requires the following instruments/ equipment

  • Diagnostic/ operative hysteroscope
  • Fluid for distension (normal saline or electrolyte free solutions like glycine)
  • Fluid management system – Hysteromat. This helps calculate the fluid deficit and prevents fluid overload
  • Light source
  • Camera system
  • Instruments like Sim’s speculum and Vulsellum

A gas insufflator is used in laparoscopy where most commonly CO2 is insufflated into the peritoneal cavity. CO2 can be used in hysteroscopy also but only in diagnostic procedures and not in operative hysteroscopy as is mentioned in the question

Ref: Page no 793, Novak's Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery
External iliac artery
Superior vesical artery

questions.text: During an abdominal hysterectomy for leiomyoma, the uterine artery slips from the clamp and there is heavy bleeding intra-operatively. The uterine artery is a branch of?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Anterior division of internal iliac artery

  • The uterine artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Branches of the internal iliac artery: Anterior and Posterior
  • Branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
  • Inferior gluteal
  • Internal pudendal
  • Middle rectal
  • Inferior vesical
  • Superior vesical
  • Uterine
  • Vaginal
  • Obturator
  • Branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery
  • Superior gluteal
  • Iliolumbar
  • Lateral Sacral

 

Ref: Page no 91, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 10th edition

choices.text: Vault infection
Peritonitis
Ureterovaginal fistula
Vaginal candidiasis

questions.text: A 54y woman underwent a total laparoscopic hysterectomy for AUB. 2 weeks following surgery, she presented with continuous watery vaginal discharge. There was no fever and abdominal examination was normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Ureterovaginal fistula.

  • Urinary (ureteric and bladder) injuries following hysterectomy are common
  • They are most common following laparoscopic hysterectomy. 

 

Common sites of ureteral injuries

  • Cardinal ligament (where the ureter crosses under the uterine artery): Most common site of ureterc injury
  • Tunnel of Wertheim
  • Dorsal to the Infundibulopelvic ligament near or at the pelvic brim
  • Lateral pelvic sidewall above the uterosacral ligament

Other Options

1. Vault infection: This would present with foul smelling vaginal discharge, bleeding and generalized symotoms of infection like pain, fever

2. Peritonitis: This would present with abdominal pain, guarding, rigidity and fever

3. Vaginal candidiasis: This would present with curdy white vaginal discharge

Ref: Page no 962, Te Linde’s Operative Gynecology 10th edition

choices.text: 1d, 2c, 3a, 4b
1c, 2a, 3b, 4d
1d, 2a, 3b, 4c
1c, 2d, 3b, 4a

questions.text: Match the diagnosis with the best route of surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1c, 2a, 3b , 4d.

  • The best route for hysterectomy depends on several factors including size of the uterus, presence or absence of ovarian mass, surgery for malignancy etc. and also on any comorbid conditions.
  • Minimally invasive techniques i.e. vaginal hysterectomy (including non-descent vaginal hysterectomy) and Laparoscopic hysterectomy are now preferred.
  • For a uterus < 14 weeks size (for e.g. adenomyosis), non-descent vaginal hysterectomy is the preferred route
  • For an ovarian malignancy, an abdominal hysterectomy (part of staging laparotomy) is done
  • For utero-vaginal prolapse, a vaginal hysterectomy is done
  • For a fibroid uterus, a laparoscopic hysterectomy can be done. (An abdominal hysterectomy can also be done but minimally invasive surgeries is preferable)

 

Ref: https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/06/choosing-the-route-of-hysterectomy-for-benign-disease

choices.text: Uterine artery
Fallopian tube and round ligament
Uterosacral ligament
None of the above

questions.text: In vaginal hysterectomy, the first clamp includes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Uterosacral ligament

Steps of a Vaginal Hysterectomy

  • Circumferential incision around the cervix
  • Anteriorly, separate the anterior vaginal wall from the cervix and open the Utero vesical fold of peritoneum; keep bladder retracted away
  • Posteriorly separate the posterior vaginal wall from the cervix and enter the Pouch of Douglas.
  • Laterally start clamping: (From below upward):
    • Uterosacral ligaments
    • Mackenrodt ligaments
    • Uterine artery
    • Cornual structures (Round ligament/ ovarian ligament/ fallopian tube complex)

Ref: Page 1116, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Least number of incisions on the uterine surface
Prefer incisions on the posterior surface of the uterus
A Bonney’s hood can be used to approach posterior large myomas
A tourniquet at the level of the uterine arteries can reduce blood loss

questions.text: A 32-year woman with multiple large fibroids is being planned for myomectomy. All are principles of myomectomy EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Prefer incisions on the posterior surface of the uterus.

Principles of myomectomy surgery

  • The surgeon must consider the location of the myomas before deciding on the incision.
  • The most preferred incision is a vertical incision on the anterior surface of the uterus. This minimizes blood loss and keeps the ovaries from adhering to the posterior wall of the uterus postoperatively.
  • Avoid posterior incisions.
  • Posterior fibroids can be removed through an anterior uterine incision, which avoids the hazards of a posterior incision.
  • Another method for approaching the posterior myoma has been described by Bonney and is called the Bonney hood.
  • Fig: The Bonny hood is demonstrated. A fundal posterior incision is made to enucleate the myomas. After reapproximating the uterine muscle, the excess serosa is draped over the fundus and fixed to the anterior surface of the uterus with fine suture. This creates a functional anterior uterine incision out of a posterior incision.
  • The general strategy employed for removing a myoma regardless of location involves incising through the pseudo capsule of the myoma.
  • The uterine serosa is sutured in a running “baseball” fashion, exposing a minimum of suture, and minimizing adhesion formation

 

 

Fig: Myomectomy technique. A. An anterior vertical uterine incision is made when possible. B. The pseudo capsule is incised, exposing the tissue planes. C. Blunt and sharp dissection of the pseudo capsule exposes the stalk of the myoma. D. The remaining attachment of the myoma to the uterus is ligated and incised. If possible, myomas are removed from this incision, avoiding a second incision. E. The uterine muscle is reapproximated using layered interrupted delayed-absorbable suture. F. The uterine serosa is sutured in a running “baseball” fashion, exposing a minimum of suture, and minimizing adhesion formation.

 

Ref: https://www.glowm.com/section-view/heading/Myomectomy/item/40#.ZAeMyHZBy5c

choices.text: Asherman Syndrome
Endometritis
Endometrial hyperplasia
Septate uterus

questions.text: A 34y woman who presented with scanty periods following an abortion 6 months earlier undergoes a diagnostic hysteroscopy. This is the finding. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Asherman Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • This image is showing intra-uterine synechiae (Adhesions) typically seen in Asherman syndrome
  • Asherman syndrome presents as
    • Hypomenorrhea (reduced menstrual flow) OR
    • Secondary amenorrhoea OR
    • Secondary infertility
       
  • Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

Other Options:

  • Option B: Endometritis: Findings on hysteroscopy include endometrial hyperemia, micro-polyps or endometrial interstitial edema. This would appear as shown below:

  • Option C: Endometrial Hyperplasia: This is suspected on increased endometrial thickness on an ultrasound. And is confirmed by endometrial biopsy. On Hysteroscopy, the endometrium will appear fluffy and thickened as shown

  • Option D: Septate uterus: This appears as a single band dividing the uterus into 2 cavities. It appears on hysteroscopy as shown below:

 

Educational Objective:

  • Asherman syndrome (intra uterine synechiae) commonly develops after a h/o curettage of the endometrium. It is also seen in Genital TB
  • It presents as
    • Hypomenorrhea (reduced menstrual flow) OR
    • Secondary amenorrhoea OR
    • Secondary infertility
       
  • Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Ref: Page no 372, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition
